This week, I traveled across my district and spoke to the hard-working men and women in Missouri’s 8th about the issues that matter most to them.

My annual farm tour is my favorite time of year, where I get to return to God’s country and hear from those I am honored to represent.

I had the privilege of visiting with Obed and Wanda Rhodes and their family in Bollinger County, where they operate Rhodes Farms, a cow-calf operation that includes two Century Farms on the property.

We talked about the everyday challenges farm families face—like burdensome regulations that make it harder to do something as simple as cleaning out creeks of excess rock and trees. These kinds of rules too often come from Washington without any understanding of the realities back at home.

The Rhodes family also took me down to Hurricane Creek, which runs through their farm. For more than a century, local churches have gathered there to conduct baptisms—a living reminder of the deep roots that faith and family have in our rural communities.

The Rhodes family represents the best of Missouri agriculture, faith, and tradition—and I’ll always work to make sure Washington stands with them, not against them.

I had the chance to visit Highland Dells Ranch in Jackson, where Steve Stroder and his wife Angie raise a heard of Scottish Highland cattle.

We had a great discussion about the challenges facing Missouri farm families—from the burden of high interest rates to the need for common-sense tax policies that let farmers reinvest in their operations.

That’s why the One Big Beautiful Bill includes provisions to help farmers by allowing them to fully expense outbuildings and improvements—a big win that helps family farms like Highland Dells keep growing for the next generation.

Thank you, Steve and Angie, for your warm welcome and for the hard work you put into agriculture here in Southeast Missouri. Missouri’s farm families are the backbone of our economy, and I’ll never stop fighting for you in Washington.

This week I visited Sauer Farms in Perry County, where Mike Sauer and his brother‑in‑law Paul Koeper raise honey bees alongside their 126‑acre cow/calf operation. They run black angus and charolais cows with Black Hereford bulls and maintain thriving hives too.

Mike and Paul highlighted how burdensome regulations—like the Veterinary Feed Directive (VFD) rule—tie up family farms with unnecessary paperwork and delays. That’s why I introduced the VFD Repeal Act (H.R. 5140) to eliminate this regulation and restore common-sense veterinary flexibility.  

I’ll keep working to cut red tape and stand with Missouri farm families—like the Sauers—so they can spend time raising healthy livestock and produce—not filling out forms.

We talked a lot about the struggles farmers in this area have been dealing with over the last few years. Lower commodity prices have made it harder for farmers like BT, but there is hope that new trade deals being negotiated by President Trump will lead to much improved market access for Missouri agriculture.

Missouri’s farm families feed and fuel the world. They deserve fair trade, not trade deficits. That’s why President Trump and I are fighting for better deals that put American farmers first.

My next Farm Tour stop brought me to Ryan Riley Farms, a fourth‑generation operation growing rice and soybeans in Risco down in New  Madrid County. I heard firsthand how farmers like Ryan are grappling with huge economic pressures.

Since President Trump left office in 2021, commodity prices have plummeted. The price of soybeans is down 28% and the price of rice is down over 10%, all while production costs have stayed high. Farmers like Ryan are why I fight for improved market access for our agricultural products. Increased market access like what was negotiated in President Trump's agreement with Japan is huge, but we also need to fight against unfair trade practices in countries like India and Brazil that keep our rice and soybeans out of their markets. 

We also discussed how the One Big, Beautiful Bill will help, with strengthened ARC/PLC support and tax relief that will benefit family-owned farms. But farmers are still struggling, and I will continue working with President Trump to strengthen our rural communities and ensure our farms and farmers are prioritized.

The Bootheel in Missouri is home to the best rice you will find. I sat down with Missouri Rice Farmers to discuss how I’m fighting to ensure other countries treat our rice farmers fairly. I also shared with them how the historic tax relief in The One, Big, Beautiful Bill will benefit their farms.

This bill cemented several key provisions for farmers, like the Death Tax exemption, enhanced reference pricing, and the 199A deduction, which affects 98% of farms across the country.

Additionally, we discussed President Trump’s recent trade agreement with Japan that will Increase market access for Missouri rice farmers for the first time since the 1990s.

Our rice farmers haven’t been treated fairly by other coutries, but I’m proud to be standing side by side with President Trump to give them the access they deserve.
